items.content_html:
Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

  • Specification title: ยง 5.1 Transferable MediaStreamTrack, from Media Capture and Streams Extensions
  • Specification or proposal URL (if available): https://w3c.github.io/mediacapture-extensions/#transferable-mediastreamtrack
  • Explainer URL (if available):
  • Proposal author(s) (@-mention GitHub accounts): @youennf
  • Caniuse.com URL (optional):
  • Bugzilla URL (optional): https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=267682, https://bugzil.la/1749543
  • Mozillians who can provide input (optional): @jan-ivar
  • WebKit standards-position:

Other information

Filed from news in https://webkit.org/blog/15443/news-from-wwdc24-webkit-in-safari-18-beta:

WebKit for Safari 18 beta adds support for MediaStreamTrack processing in a dedicated worker.

Transfer of MST is a prerequisite for the APIs MediaStreamTrackProcessor and VideoTrackGenerator, which in the spec are only exposed in DedicatedWorker.
items.title: Transferable MediaStreamTrack (Media Capture and Streams Extension)

items.content_html:
Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

  • Specification title: Prioritized Task Scheduling: scheduler.yield()
  • Specification or proposal URL (if available): https://wicg.github.io/scheduling-apis/#dom-scheduler-yield
  • Explainer URL (if available): https://github.com/WICG/scheduling-apis/blob/main/explainers/prioritized-task-scheduling.md#scheduleryield
  • Proposal author(s) (@-mention GitHub accounts): @shaseley
  • Caniuse.com URL (optional):
  • Bugzilla URL (optional):
  • Mozillians who can provide input (optional): @smaug---- @sefeng211
  • WebKit standards-position: WebKit/standards-positions#361

Other information

This builds on scheduler.postTask(), which I know has been prototyped but not shipped in Gecko. We recently landed WICG/scheduling-apis#92 to try to address concerns captured in WICG/scheduling-apis#67. That same concern will apply to this API, which builds on the existing prioritization in the spec.
items.title: Prioritized Task Scheduling: scheduler.yield()

items.content_html:
Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

  • Specification title: WebAssembly ESM Integration
  • Specification or proposal URL (if available): https://github.com/webassembly/esm-integration
  • Explainer URL (if available): https://github.com/WebAssembly/esm-integration/blob/main/proposals/esm-integration/README.md
  • Proposal author(s) (@-mention GitHub accounts): @linclark, @littledan, @Ms2ger, @takikawa, @guybedford
  • Caniuse.com URL (optional):
  • Bugzilla URL (optional): https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1899832
  • Mozillians who can provide input (optional): @codehag @eqrion
  • WebKit standards-position:

Other information

The WebAssembly ESM Integration allows JS modules to import Wasm and vice versa, providing improved ergonomics and tooling workflows when working with WebAssembly modules. With Source Phase Imports it also allows the ability to import uninstantiated Wasm through the module system enabling these benefits for the full range of instantiation workflows. While it has been in development for some time, it was recently progressed to Phase 3 in the WebAssembly process.
items.title: WebAssembly ESM Integration

items.content_html:
Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

  • Specification title: ServiceWorkerAutoPreload
  • Specification or proposal URL (if available):
  • Explainer URL (if available): https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/service-worker-auto-preload
  • Proposal author(s) (@-mention GitHub accounts): @sisidovski
  • Caniuse.com URL (optional):
  • Bugzilla URL (optional):
  • Mozillians who can provide input (optional):
  • WebKit standards-position: WebKit/standards-positions#359

Other information

This API is a new loading strategy for ServiceWorker. ServiceWorkerAutoPreload is a mode where the browser issues a network request (i.e. a regular request which may result in a HTTP cache hit or an actual fetch) in parallel with the ServiceWorker bootstrap, and consumes the network request result inside the fetch handler.

The status in chromium can be tracked from https://chromestatus.com/feature/5194817700364288

This is an early-stage idea but we'd love early engagement from other implementers.
items.title: ServiceWorkerAutoPreload

items.content_html:
Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

  • Specification title: Reference Target for Cross-Root ARIA
  • Specification or proposal URL (if available): https://github.com/WICG/aom/blob/gh-pages/reference-target-explainer.md
  • Explainer URL (if available): https://github.com/WICG/aom/blob/gh-pages/reference-target-explainer.md
  • Proposal author(s) (@-mention GitHub accounts): @behowell, @alice & @Westbrook
  • Caniuse.com URL (optional):
  • Bugzilla URL (optional):
  • Mozillians who can provide input (optional): @smaug----, @zcorpan
  • WebKit standards-position:

Other information

Reference Targets allow forwarding IDREFs to members of the ShadowDOM which will make it signficantly easier to create web components which rely on ARIA (which itself heavily relies on IDREFs).

The Web Components Community Group considers this a pivotol feature, and as such I am happy to prototype an implementation in Gecko to help steer this feature.
items.title: Reference Target for Cross-Root ARIA

items.content_html:
Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

  • Specification title: Content Security Policy (and Trusted Types)
  • Specification or proposal URL (if available): w3c/webappsec-csp@8444566
  • Explainer URL (if available):
  • Proposal author(s) (@-mention GitHub accounts): @lukewarlow
  • Caniuse.com URL (optional):
  • Bugzilla URL (optional):
  • Mozillians who can provide input (optional): @mozfreddyb @dveditz
  • WebKit standards-position: WebKit/standards-positions#355

Other information

This proposes a new trusted-types-eval keyword for the CSP script-src directive. The main use case for this new keyword is to allow enabling eval only in browsers that support and have Trusted Types enforced. Currently trusted types is used alongside unsafe-eval (if you need eval), which means that in browsers with no trusted types support eval is still allowed (completely unmitigated by the protections TT offer). This new keyword would prevent that situation.
items.title: New `trusted-types-eval` keyword for CSP script-src

items.content_html:
Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

  • Specification Title: Timing Info for ServiceWorker static routing API
  • Specification or proposal URL (if available):
  • Explainer URL (if available): explainer
  • Proposal author(s) (@-mention GitHub accounts): @quasi-mod, @yoshisatoyanagisawa
  • Caniuse.com URL (optional):
  • Bugzilla URL (optional):
  • Mozillians who can provide input (optional):
  • WebKit standards-position: WebKit/standards-positions#354

Other information

Service Worker provides timing information to mark certain points in time. This is exposed and used by the navigation timing API as well as the resource timing API. It currently records two times:

  • Start time
  • Fetch event dispatch time

However, it currently does not have any fields related to the ServiceWorker Static Routing API. Developers would benefit from having fields that provide information such as:

  • the matched route (the route that the Static Routing API evaluated)
  • the actual source from which the resource was retrieved
  • the time it took to match the route
  • the time to look up the cache for the cache source

This information will allow developers to measure the latency incurred by the API such as router evaluation time or time required to conduct cache lookup, or determine if the matched source is the final source used (can find out if the matched source failed to get the resource or not, and which source was used as the alternative).
items.title: Timing Info for ServiceWorker static routing API

Other information

Firefox already has almost all features of the specification. So I think this is "positive".
However, I'd like to know positions of some unsupported parts like:

  • Breaking Within Bases
  • Line-edge Alignment

We are implementing them in Chromium.

items.content_html:
Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

  • Specification title: improved styling of <details> and <summary> elements
  • Specification or proposal URL: Not a single spec, but a set of changes initially discussed in openui/open-ui#744 and now moved to w3c/csswg-drafts#9879 and whatwg/html#10265 for the parts that belong in CSS and HTML respectively.
  • Explainer URL (if available): https://github.com/dbaron/details-styling
  • Proposal author(s) (@-mention GitHub accounts): @dbaron
  • Caniuse.com URL (optional): none
  • Bugzilla URL (optional): One piece of it is covered by https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1856374 but other bugs are needed for other parts.
  • Mozillians who can provide input (optional): @emilio
  • WebKit standards-position:

Other information

I realize this is perhaps a little fuzzy, but I think most specifically it's useful to have a position on:

  • the set of changes in whatwg/html#10265
  • the addition of the ::details-content pseudo-element.
items.title: improved styling of <details> and <summary> elements

items.content_html:
Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

  • Specification title: Partitioned Popins
  • GitHub URL: https://github.com/arichiv/partitioned-popins/
  • Explainer URL: https://github.com/arichiv/partitioned-popins/blob/main/README.md
  • Spec URL: TBD
  • Proposal authors: @arichiv @johannhof @krgovind
  • Bug Tracker URL: https://issues.chromium.org/issues/340606651
  • Chrome Feature URL: https://chromestatus.com/feature/5949561398099968
  • Mozillians who can provide input: @bvandersloot-mozilla
  • WebKit standards-position: WebKit/standards-positions#349
  • Tag Review: w3ctag/design-reviews#956

Other information

A new web primitive is needed to cover short-lived popup use cases which require access to storage partitioned by the popup opener. This primitive should be private and secure by default, while providing a consistent UI experience across user agents. To solve this need, we propose the โPartitioned Popinโ, a type of pop-up for loading web content with two unique new features: a modal-like UI relative to its opener tab and cookies/storage being partitioned to its opener context.
items.title: Partitioned Popins
